title: Plea for people to attend funeral of D-Day veteran and give him hero's send off
text:

An appeal has been made for people to attend the funeral of a D-Day war hero who has died at the age of 101.

Reginald 'Reg' Tegg risked his life to clear minefields during Nazi attacks and was part of a valiant rear-guard defence during the 1940 Dunkirk evacuation.

Mr Tegg has no friend and very little family so it is feared that the 'quiet' veteran will not get the hero's send-off he deserves following his death at a nursing home.

A military association has launched an urgent appeal for mourners to pay their respects at his funeral next week, which is so far only expected to be attended by a handful of surviving relatives.

(Image: Portsmouth News/Solent News)

Heroic Mr Tegg, a Sapper with the Royal Engineers, died at a nursing home in Sarisbury Green, near Southampton, Hants, on September 22.

He served in three major amphibious assaults against the Germans, avoiding death during invasions of Sicily, Italy, and Normandy, France, in the Second World War.

Mr Tegg was part of the first wave to land on Gold Beach during the pivotal invasion of Normandy on June 6, 1944 - six days before his 26th birthday.

Under constant fire, he was tasked with clearing the beach of Nazi mines and was later awarded France's highest military honour for bravery - the Légion d'Honneur.

(Image: Portsmouth News/Solent News)

Solent and District Branch Royal Engineers Association, issued the appeal after hearing of the war hero's death.

The Iraq and Afghanistan veteran said: "I sadly never had the chance to meet Reg. But as soon as I heard he had died I knew we had to do something.

"Reg's generation - the greatest generation - is now very few in number. These guys were willing, without a moment's hesitation, to put themselves in the firing line to save their country and the world from Nazism.

"It's vitally important we remember them."

(Image: Portsmouth News/Solent News)

Mr Tegg is survived by his daughter Mandy, three grandchildren - Ashley, 22, Nathan, 21, and Marshall, 16 - wife Mary, 86, and nephew Martin Oates, 55.

The funeral will be held at Portchester Crematorium, near Fareham, Hants, at 11.15am on October 15.

Hundreds of people have already responded to a Facebook plea to attend the funeral and pay tribute to Reg.

Mandy, 47, was stunned by the response and said: "It has brought me to tears more than once.

"He was a doting grandfather who loved his grandchildren. They couldn't have asked for a better grandfather."

Nephew Mr Oates - a Royal Navy chief petty officer - added: "He was 101 and for six of those years it was carnage, stress and chaos.

"He lived peacefully after that. He was a quiet hero."
description: Reginald 'Reg' Tegg, who risked his his life to clear minefields during Nazi attacks, died at the age of 101 and has very little family
